The regulatory effect of Fur on the promoter exbBp is not yet known. However, we assigned a negative effect to this regulatory interaction based on two facts: (1) the protein's binding site overlaps the -35 box of the promoter; and (2) Fur is known to act, so far without exceptions, as a negative regulator.

This is an FNR half-site. The activation of hypB is completely dependent on the site at the -43.5 position, but two sites (-149.5 and -43.5) are required for maximum induction. It is suggested that tandem FNR half-sites may be features of genes active under anaerobic conditions that are subject to transcription initiation from both σ54 and σ70 promoters.
IHF (-115 site) increases FNR-dependent activation by decreasing the repression mediated by IHF (-88 site) and Fis (-142 site). It is a weak site.

Based on the effect of various concentrations of GalS on the gal regulon promoter and mathematical models, it was determined that GalS has higher affinity for galSOE, which is at position -61.5 on the galS promoter |CITS:[19429616]|. This effect is referred to as dominant negative autoregulation |CITS:[19429616]|.

An interesting characteristic of the regulation of the ilvLBN operon is that even though CRP can activate it,
attenuation can trump any activation by CRP and absolutely stop ilvLBN transcription |CITS: [6095192]|.

When the CTP level within the cell is high relative to the level of GTP, the pyrC gene is transcribed from a start site that allows formation of a secondary structure within the 5' end of the mRNA. This hairpin structure is thought to obscure the Shine-Dalgarno sequence, and it results in poor translation efficiency. When the CTP level is low relative to the level of GTP, pyrC is transcribed from an alternate start site. This shorter mRNA is translated efficiently. The PurR protein, which represses the pyrC gene, is also regulated by the level of GTP, because this protein is active when GTP is present.

The precise position and the length of this binding site were identified by the curator, who used a new predictive methodology, PhyPIR (Phylogenetic Profile of Inverted Repeated patterns), which was developed in the laboratory of Dr. Enrique Merino of the Institute of Biotechnology, UNAM.

Evidence supports the existence of a regulatory element controlling induction under oxygen-limiting conditions in aidB. The aidB mRNA start site is identical whether induction occurs via Ada-dependent or Ada-independent pathway.

This site is the strongest Fis-binding site among the five. It overlaps with the RNA polymerase binding site, and it is deviates significantly from the Fis modified consensus sequence.
Fur binds DNA at a site between the -10 and -35 regions of the tonB promoter under aerobic and anaerobic conditions, but only when iron is present in excess .

MelR binding to site 2' (-194.5) occurs only in the presence of melibiose |CITS:[12060687]| and relieves MelR-dependent repression of the melR promoter |CITS:[12060687], [10760179], [10747919], [1445208], [10760178]|.

Previously, two binding sites for the NagC repressor were detected upstream of manX, but a mutation in nagC has very little effect on manX expression. Plasmids overproducing either the NagC protein or the Mlc protein repress the expression of manX, but the effect of the Mlc protein is stronger |CITS: [9484892], [1848637]|.

Purified OxyR and IHF proteins have also been shown to bind upstream from the dps promoter. OxyR and σS act independently to regulate the level of the Dps protein in the log and the stationary phases. Regulation of dps by σS and OxyR is independent in vivo, and OxyR probably does not activate σS holoenzyme. OxyR and IHF proteins may occupy the dps promoter simultaneously |CITS: [7984106]|.
Stimulation of the nfop promoter was independent of the C-terminal domain of the RNA polymerase α-subunit. The binding site overlaps the -35 promoter hexamer.

The effect of FruR repression of the adhE gene was studied under aerobic and anaerobic growth conditions, and stronger repression was observed during aerobic growth. Neither respiratory condition implies direct regulation, but they may reflect a difference of fructose or fructose-1,6-diphosphate levels |CITS: [9371462]|. Later, the FruR site was localized downstream of the promoter, and it has been proposed as a repressor site |CITS: [12083772]| (as it has been observed that other FruR repressor sites are overlapping or downstream of the promoter) (see |CITS: [8655535]|).

In the absence of the other proteins, cAMP-CRP binds to three CRP targets centered at -92.5 (CRP2), -42.5 (CRP1), and +56 (CRPE).
The nupG full repression complex contains CytR protein sandwiched between two cAMP-CRP complexes.

The nupG full repression complex contains the CytR protein sandwiched between two cAMP-CRP complexes. Binding of CytR to its target excludes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP1 and promotes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP0, therefore allowing cooperative binding of the two protein species.

The nupG full repression complex contains the CytR protein sandwiched between two cAMP-CRP complexes. Binding of CytR to its target excludes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP1 and promotes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP0, therefore allowing cooperative binding of the two protein species.
The CRP function in the promoter for treB is not known, but the position of the binding site on this promoter suggests that CRP is a repressor of this promoter.

Based on genome-wide analysis, it was discovered that CRP downregulates the expression of the mdtEF gene cluster, and a novel uncharacterized physiological role for CRP in multidrug resistance has been described by Nishino et al. (2008). |CITS:[18503189]| .
RstA activates csgDEFG only under acidic conditions at low pH |CITS: [20466769]|.

Localization at -49.5 of CRP activating the aer promoter is unusual from any previously characterized CRP-activated promoter. However, this position is optimal for activation by σ28 |CITS:[19843224]|. In addition, CRP activates transcription of the aer promoter by recruitment of RNA polymerase |CITS:[19843224]|.
Two α-CTD of Eσ28 contact DNA both upstream and downstream of CRP |CITS:[19843224]|. A model for the organization of the CRP- Eσ28-DNA ternary complex at the aer promoter proposed by Hollands et al. (2009) differs substantially from the CRP- Eσ70-DNA complex at the class I σ70-dependent promoter |CITS:[19843224]|.
NsrR plays a major role while the effects of NarL and NarP are minimal in the regulation of the hcp-hcr operon by nitrate and nitrite |CITS: [20533909]|.
The site of the RutR-regulating rutABCDEFG may hinder contact between NtrC and σ54 by stiffening the DNA between the enhancer and the promoter |CITS:[1776167]|.
H-NS blocks dps transcription by displacing RNA polymerase |CITS:[18452510]|.

CreB is a response regulator that activates transcription of the talA gene. In 2001, M. Avison et al. identified a possible binding site for CreB, TTCACGTAACGTTCAC, in the upstream region of this gene |CITS:[11350954]|. The predicted binding site of CreB has been identified based on similarity to the consensus sequence (acTTCACnnnnacTTCAC) and demonstration of its function based on gene expression analysis |CITS:[ 11350954]|. This regulator requires one direct repeat binding site of 18 bp to activate transcription of the talA gene.

This is a CRP-S site that requires the Sxy transcriptional coactivator |CITS: [25491382]|.
Salmon et al. |CITS: [15699038]| identified a putative ArcA-binding site upstream of the rpsJp promoter, but the sequence was not reported.

M. Avison et al. in 2001 identified a possible binding site for CreB, TTCACCTGAGATTCAC, in the upstream region of the radC gene |CITS:[11350954]|. CreB is a response regulator that activates transcription of this gene. The predicted binding site of CreB has been identified based on similarity to the consensus sequence (acTTCACnnnnacTTCAC) and demonstration of its function based on gene expression analysis |CITS:[11350954]|. The transcription start site for this gene has not been identified; for this reason, the binding site has no central position.
This response regulator requires one direct repeat binding site of 18 bp to activate transcription of the radC gene.

By making use of microarray analyses, Constantinidou et al. |CITS: [16377617]| concluded that FNR activates tar-tap-cheRBYZ operon expression. They also identified a putative FNR-binding site upstream of the operon, but the sequence was not reported.

NimR-binding site-3
A palindromic sequence, CTCATTTG(T)ACAATGAG, designated NimR box-1, was identified within the NimR-binding site-3 |CITS:[25790494]|.
A putative DpiA-binding site, which is an A+T-rich sequence, is located upstream of the appY gene |CITS: [9701802]|.

NimR-binding site-1
A palindromic sequence, CTCATTTG(T)ACAATGAG, designated NimR box-1, was identified within the NimR-binding site-1. The NimR-binding site-1 and site-3 are located in close proximity to the nimR and nimT promoters, respectively |CITS:[25790494]|.

M. Avison et al. in 2001 demonstrated that the response regulator CreB activated transcription of the first gene (trgB) of this operon, and they also identified a possible binding site for CreB, TTCACATTTAATTCAC, in the upstream region of the gene |CITS:[11350954]|. The predicted binding site of CreB has been identified based on similarity to the consensus sequence (acTTCACnnnnacTTCAC) and demonstration of its function based on gene expression analysis |CITS:[11350954]|. The transcription start site for this operon has not been identified; for this reason, the binding site has no central position.
This response regulator requires one direct repeat binding site of 18 bp to activate transcription of the trgB gene.
MarA represses rob by steric hindrance |CITS:[20453091]|. This mar box has a backward orientation |CITS:[20453091]|.

The sequence proposed as a possible Lrp binding site (GGAGTATTATCGTGA) is centered at -21 bp
from the gene translation start site |CITS: [8521047]|.
The inhibition of transcription by IHF is relieved by TyrR. IHF does not bind specifically to tyrP promoter.

In the total absence of galactose, HU and GalR repress the expression of the gal operon. But at low concentrations of galactose, GalR, bound to just one site at position -55.5, activates the expression of the operon through the galp2 promoter |CITS: [16524589]|.

It has been proven that HNS has regulatory effects for the ilvIH operon under high osmolarity conditions, decreasing the Lrp action; these effects superimpose the Lrp activation of the operon |CITS:[8152423]|.
UspE regulates positively the transcription of the gadX gene in an unknown way, and GadX induces the transcription of uspE |CITS:[ 20209085]|.

The central position of the CRP binding site (AAATtTGATtaAccgCACcTaa) has been identified by similarity to the consensus sequence AAATGTGATCTAGATCACATTT (using the SIGNALX program) and it is located at -25.5 bp from the uxuR start codon.

NimR-binding site-2
A common sequence, TAACAA, designated NimR box-2, was identified within both NimR site-2 and site-3 |CITS:[25790494]|.

The specific binding site of AccB at the accBC promoter region has not been determined, but the regulation and
direct evidences have shown been shown at |CITS: [14594796]|.

Rob is a transcriptional regulator related with the increase in resistance to antibiotics and is expressed constitutively. Bennik et al have shown that this regulator activates the transcription of yfhD gene |CITS [ 10850996 ]|.

There are four putative sites to bind MarA, but just one at position -43.5 is necessary to activate the transcription of nfnB. In vitro, but not in vivo, the proteins Rob and SoxS activate the transcription of nfnB and they bind to the MarA-binding site when they are present in a high concentration.

CreB is a response regulator that activates transcription of the ackA-pta operon. In 2001, M. Avison et al. identified a possible binding site for CreB, TTCACCTCAACTTCAC, in the upstream region of the operon |CITS:[11350954]|. The predicted binding site of CreB has been identified based on similarity to the consensus sequence (acTTCACnnnnacTTCAC) and demonstration of its function based on gene expression analysis |CITS:[ 11350954]|. The transcription start site for this operon has not been identified; for this reason, the binding site has no central position.
This response regulator requires one direct repeat binding site of 18 bp to activate transcription of the ackA-pta operon.

M. Avison et al. in 2001 identified a possible binding site for CreB, TTCACACTCCCTTCAC, in the upstream region of the yieI gene |CITS:[11350954]|. CreB is a response regulator that activates transcription of this gene. The predicted binding site of CreB has been identified based on similarity to the consensus sequence (acTTCACnnnnacTTCAC) and demonstration of its function based on gene expression analysis |CITS:[11350954]|. The transcription start site for this gene has not been identified; for this reason, the binding site has no central position.
This response regulator requires one direct repeat binding site of 18 bp to activate transcription of the yieI gene.
The specific site sequence for Rob binding at the acrAp promoter has not been reported yet |CITS: [12791142]|.
ArcA repressed the ubiCA operon under anaerobiosis conditions |CITS:[15902464]|.

The central position of the UxuR binding site (tAtTTGGTtgACCAgTTT) has been identified by similarity to the consensus sequence AAATTGGTATACCAATTT (using the SIGNALX program) and it is located at -165.5 bp from the uxuR start codon |CITS:[ 11115104]|.
